### SesameOp: Novel backdoor uses OpenAI Assistants API for command and control


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article discusses a new cybersecurity threat called "SesameOp," which utilizes the OpenAI Assistants API as a novel method for command and control in backdoor attacks. By leveraging the widespread availability and versatility of OpenAI's language models, malicious actors are able to discreetly communicate with compromised systems. The attackers integrate this method into their strategy to avoid detection by traditional security measures, making it a sophisticated and concerning development for cybersecurity experts. The article emphasizes the need for heightened awareness and enhanced defense mechanisms to

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2025/11/03/sesameop-novel-backdoor-uses-openai-assistants-api-for-command-and-control/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_2485)**

### Aisuru Botnet Shifts from DDoS to Residential Proxies


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The Aisuru botnet, initially known for executing Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks, has transitioned its operations towards establishing a network of residential proxies. This shift allows the botnet's operators to leverage compromised devices, particularly routers and IoT gadgets, to mask their activities and provide proxy services that disguise malicious traffic as legitimate residential data. This adaptation enhances the botnet's capabilities in evading detection and improves the effectiveness of cybercriminal acts by bypassing traditional security measures. Researchers

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2025/10/aisuru-botnet-shifts-from-ddos-to-residential-proxies/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_8781)**

### Chicago Sun Times: ICE has powerful facial recognition app Illinois cops are barred from using ‚Äî with little apparent oversight


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


Illinois law enforcement agencies are prohibited from using a powerful facial recognition app provided by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) due to state regulations. The app allows users to upload photos and compare them against a database of millions of images, potentially identifying individuals for immigration enforcement. Despite this restriction in Illinois, the article highlights concerns over the lack of transparency and oversight regarding how and where this technology is utilized, raising questions about privacy and the potential for misuse in other jurisdictions where such regulations are not in

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://epic.org/chicago-sun-times-ice-has-powerful-facial-recognition-app-illinois-cops-are-barred-from-using-with-little-apparent-oversight/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_8568)**

### The 5 generative AI security threats you need to know about detailed in new e-book


üõ°Ô∏è **SECURITY ALERT**


A recent e-book has outlined five critical security threats posed by generative AI technologies. These include the misuse of AI for generating phishing attacks and deepfake materials that make deceptive content more convincing and widespread. Additionally, there's concern over AI models being manipulated to leak sensitive information or to amplify misinformation. The e-book also highlights the risks associated with AI systems being compromised through adversarial attacks, which could alter their outputs in harmful ways. Lastly, the potential for AI to be used in automating and increasing the

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2025/10/30/the-5-generative-ai-security-threats-you-need-to-know-about-detailed-in-new-e-book/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_9586)**

### Suspected Nation-State Threat Actor Uses New Airstalk Malware in a Supply Chain Attack


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article discusses a sophisticated cyberattack attributed to a suspected nation-state threat actor, which employed a newly identified malware called "Airstalk" in a supply chain attack. The attack targeted a prominent software vendor, allowing the perpetrators to infiltrate and compromise the systems of various downstream organizations relying on the vendor's software. The malware is described as highly advanced, with capabilities for stealthy data exfiltration and lateral movement within networks. Security experts are actively analyzing Airstalk to mitigate its impact and prevent

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/new-windows-based-malware-family-airstalk/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_154)**

### Microsoft Detects "SesameOp" Backdoor Using OpenAI's API as a Stealth Command Channel


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


Microsoft has identified a new cybersecurity threat called "SesameOp," which utilizes OpenAI's API as a stealthy command and control channel for a backdoor. This sophisticated method exploits the API's capabilities to mask malicious communication within legitimate data exchanges, making it challenging to detect. By leveraging the natural language processing abilities of OpenAI's platform, the attackers can issue commands that appear harmless, allowing them to manipulate infected systems without raising suspicion. This discovery highlights the increasing complexity of cyber threats and underscores the importance

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://thehackernews.com/2025/11/microsoft-detects-sesameop-backdoor.html?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_6026)**

### Microsoft: SesameOp malware abuses OpenAI Assistants API in attacks


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article discusses a new malware named SesameOp, which exploits vulnerabilities in OpenAI's Assistants API to conduct cyberattacks. Developed by Microsoft, the report highlights how SesameOp uses this access to manipulate AI responses and execute malicious activities, potentially affecting users who interact with compromised systems. The malware's sophistication lies in its ability to seamlessly blend with normal functionalities of AI tools, making detection challenging. Microsoft underscores the importance of heightened security measures and monitoring to protect against such innovative threats, emphasizing collaboration between tech

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/microsoft-sesameop-malware-abuses-openai-assistants-api-in-attacks/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_6757)**
